events.summary: Juan II returns to Toledo after seven days of hard riding from the Cortes at Valladolid. He finds Isabel eight months pregnant and emotionally fragile from weeks alone. They reunite in their chambers where Juan removes his armor — a symbolic and practical gesture — and Isabel helps unbuckle a piece he cannot reach. She asks him to pray together in the Portuguese chapel and he agrees to stay until the birth.

CHAPTER 29: THE RETURN HOME

Date: November 16, 1431, Afternoon
Location: Toledo, Royal Alcázar

The white destrier's hooves clatter on Toledo's cobblestones as you ride through the gates. Seven days hard riding from Valladolid—faster than the nobles' leisurely departure, faster than the wagons carrying parchments and proclamations. The Cortes is over. The Crown Marshals are appointed. The taxation secured. Three houses condemned.

And Isabel is eight months pregnant.

The journey north blurs in memory—pushing hard, changing horses twice, your escort exhausted but uncomplaining. Álvaro stayed behind to coordinate implementation. Don Rodrigo returned to the frontier. You came home.

Servants recognize your armor as you dismount in the Alcázar's courtyard. A groom rushes forward to take your horse. Palace doors open—courtiers emerging, bowing, murmuring welcomes. News of the Cortes' success has obviously preceded you.

But you barely register them.

Through the entrance, past the great hall, toward the royal apartments—and there, emerging from the corridor that leads to your chambers, is Dona Beatriz de Meneses. Isabel's lady-in-waiting sees you and her face transforms with relief.

"Your Majesty! Thank God—she's been watching from the windows all afternoon. The scouts reported your approach an hour ago and she's been—" Beatriz catches herself, curtsies quickly. "She's in your chambers, Your Majesty. Waiting."

Behind Beatriz, through the open doorway, you catch a glimpse of blue fabric. Movement.

Then Isabel appears in the doorway.

Eight months pregnant—enormously so. Her belly strains against the deep blue gown, both hands resting beneath it for support. Her face is fuller, tired shadows beneath her eyes, but those eyes lock onto you with an intensity that stops your breath.

She takes one halting step forward, then another. Dona Beatriz moves to support her elbow but Isabel barely seems to notice.

"Juan."

Just your name. But the way she says it—relief, joy, exhaustion, fear, love—everything compressed into one word.

She's perhaps ten paces away, moving carefully, very pregnant, very close to her time. The afternoon light from the corridor windows catches her plainness and makes it almost beautiful.
I walk up to her and carefully hold her and help her into a chair or bed, whatever she is comfortable in.

Isabel is 8 months pregnant, exhausted from worry, relieved he's home. She's been alone for weeks while he was at the Cortes. The baby is due in about 6-8 weeks (late January/early February 1432). She's been terrified during his absence, as established in Chapter 23.

I should not write Juan's dialogue or thoughts - only Isabel's responses and the world around them.

You close the distance quickly, armor still dusty from the road. Your hands find her shoulders—gently, carefully—and she leans into you immediately, her swollen belly pressing against your side. She's trembling slightly.

"I'm here," you murmur. "Come, sit down."

Isabel nods, letting you guide her. She gestures toward the bed rather than the chairs—"Easier to get comfortable"—and you help her settle against the pillows. It takes several adjustments, cushions repositioned under her back and beneath her belly, before she finds a position that doesn't make her wince.

When she's finally comfortable, she reaches for your hand and doesn't let go.

"Three weeks," she says quietly. "You've been gone three weeks. I know it's not long compared to the campaign, but Juan—" Her voice catches. "The baby's so close now. Every morning I wake up thinking 'what if today? What if he's not here?' And then the reports came from Valladolid about the resistant nobles, about the condemnations, and I thought—"

She stops herself, squeezes your hand tighter. The carved Virgin Mary from August sits on the bedside table, well-worn from constant handling.

"I'm sorry. You're here now. That's what matters." She takes a shaky breath. "Tell me—is it over? The Cortes? Did they... did the nobles accept everything?"

Dona Beatriz quietly withdraws, closing the door behind her to give you privacy. Through the window, you can hear the distant sounds of Toledo—merchants calling, church bells ringing vespers, the ordinary life of the city continuing outside these walls.

Isabel watches your face intently, waiting for your answer, one hand still gripping yours and the other resting protectively on her belly.

The Cortes went well. We dont have to worry about it. Everyone was in agreement.


How are you love? I dont have to go anywhere until you have given birth.

Relief floods Isabel's face so completely that tears spill over. She doesn't try to hide them.

"You promise? You won't have to leave?" Her voice breaks slightly. "Because Juan, I'm so tired. The baby's dropped lower this past week—the physicians say it could be any day now, or it could be three more weeks, they can't tell for certain. And I've been so frightened that you wouldn't make it back in time, that I'd be alone when—"

She stops, swallows hard, trying to compose herself. "I'm sorry. I know I shouldn't be like this. Queens are supposed to be strong, and I've tried, but—"

Her free hand moves to her belly as the baby shifts visibly beneath the fabric. She winces slightly at what must be an uncomfortable kick.

"I'm well enough, physically. The physicians say everything is as it should be. The baby's active—very active. Strong." A small, exhausted smile. "Dona Beatriz jokes that he fights already, the way he kicks. If it's a boy."

She looks at you directly then, eyes red but steady. "I'm just... I'm tired, Juan. Tired of being afraid. Tired of waiting. Tired of watching from windows wondering if you'll come home." She squeezes your hand again. "But you're here now. And you promise you'll stay?"

There's something almost childlike in the question—this sixteen-year-old girl, enormously pregnant, who's spent months accumulating fears while you've been commanding armies and negotiating with nobles.

I am still in my armour and start doffing it.


I dont need my armour any more. Ill stay with you Isabel. dont worry.

The armor removal is both practical and symbolic - he's done being the crusader king for now, he's going to be her husband and the father of her child.

You stand and begin unbuckling the straps, pulling at the leather fastenings. The breastplate comes away first, then the pauldrons. Each piece of white armor—dusty from seven days of hard riding—clatters onto the nearby table.

Isabel watches you, something shifting in her expression. When you struggle with one of the arm pieces, she pushes herself up slightly. "Let me—"

Her fingers work at the buckle you can't quite reach, slower than a squire would manage but steady. The intimacy of it—her helping you remove your armor, the two of you alone in your chambers—seems to calm her. The trembling in her hands eases.

"I like this better," she says quietly as the vambrace comes free. "You without the armor. Just... you."

The last pieces come away. You're left in the padded gambeson beneath, stained with sweat from the journey. You pull that off too, reaching for the clean shirt that's laid out.

Isabel settles back against the pillows, watching you with tired eyes that hold something softer now. Not the accumulated fear. Just exhaustion and relief.

"Three weeks until Christmas," she says. "Maybe the baby will come before then. Or after. The physicians truly don't know." She touches her belly again. "Will you pray with me tonight? I've been keeping up our evening prayers, but it's not the same without you. The chapel—it's been lonely."

Outside the window, the bells of Toledo's cathedral ring for vespers. The sun is beginning to set, painting the room in golden light.

events.summary: Weeks pass as Juan stays by Isabel's side through November, December, and January. They maintain their evening prayer ritual in the Portuguese chapel. Isabel grows increasingly uncomfortable as the baby grows. Christmas is celebrated at Toledo Cathedral. By late January Isabel is enormous and restless. On the evening of January 28, 1432, her contractions begin and she tells Juan to call for Dona Beatriz and the physicians.

exchanges.text: I stay with Isabel until the birth. Describe until the labour starts.

The days settle into a rhythm you've never known before—domestic, quiet, almost ordinary despite the crown you wear.

Every evening without fail, you and Isabel kneel together in the Portuguese chapel. She grows heavier, moves more slowly, but never misses the prayers. The ritual anchors both of you. Sometimes you pray the rosary in silence. Sometimes she asks you to read Scripture aloud while she rests her hands on her belly. The baby kicks during the Magnificat one evening, and Isabel laughs—the first genuine laugh you've heard from her in weeks.

The physicians visit frequently. Old Doctor Fernández, who attended your own birth, examines Isabel with careful professionalism while Dona Beatriz stands guard. "Everything proceeds well, Your Majesty. First babies often come late. Be patient."

Patience. You learn it in increments.

December arrives cold and clear. Isabel can no longer walk the palace corridors without stopping to rest. Her back aches constantly. She sleeps fitfully, waking when the baby shifts position or presses against her ribs. You hold her those nights, one hand on her belly feeling the movements—elbows, knees, impossible to tell which.

"Do you think it's a boy?" she asks one night.

"Does it matter?"

"For the kingdom it does." Always practical, your Isabel. "An heir is better than a daughter who'll need a husband."

"Then we'll have more children," you say simply. "As many as God gives us."

She's quiet for a long moment. Then: "I'm frightened of the birthing."

You know. She doesn't have to say it. Every woman knows the risks. You've seen the way Dona Beatriz watches her, the way the physicians exchange glances they think you don't notice.

"You'll be fine," you tell her. "You're strong."

"I'm not, though. Not like you." She turns awkwardly to face you in the darkness. "Promise me—if something goes wrong, if they have to choose—"

"Nothing will go wrong."

"Juan, promise me. The baby first. The kingdom needs an heir more than it needs—"

You kiss her to stop the words. "Nothing will go wrong. I won't hear talk of choosing. You'll both be fine."

She doesn't argue, but you feel her trembling against you.

Christmas arrives with its pageantry. Isabel attends Midnight Mass despite her size, sitting in a specially cushioned chair while the cathedral celebrates Christ's birth. She's radiant in candlelight, one hand on her belly throughout the liturgy.

Afterward, in private: "Next Christmas, we'll have our child with us."

"God willing," she whispers.

New Year passes. January brings bitter cold and Isabel's increasing discomfort. She's enormous now—the physicians estimate the baby weighs seven or eight pounds already. She can't sleep lying down anymore, propped up on pillows even at night. Her ankles swell. Her back never stops aching.

But she doesn't complain. Not once. She attends to her duties when she can—receiving ladies of the court, overseeing the nursery preparations, embroidering tiny gowns with shaking fingers.

"I'm ready," she tells you one evening in late January. "I want to meet our baby. I want this to be over."

You're in your chambers, her sitting in the large chair with her feet elevated, you reading to her from the Lives of the Saints. She's been restless all day—shifting positions constantly, unable to get comfortable.

"Soon," you promise.

"The physicians say any day now. They said that two weeks ago." She grimaces, adjusting her position again. "I feel so—"

She stops mid-sentence. Her hand flies to her belly. Her eyes go wide.

For a long moment, nothing. Then her face shifts—pain, surprise, something else.

"Juan." Her voice is very calm. Very controlled. "I think... I think you should call Dona Beatriz."

"What—"

"Now, please." Still that eerie calm. Then she gasps slightly as her body tenses. Her hand grips the chair arm. "The baby's coming. Call them now."

Outside, the cathedral bells ring for compline. Inside, your wife's face goes pale as another contraction hits.

The waiting is over.

Historical context:
- Maternal mortality in medieval Europe was around 1-2% per birth

Let me write this carefully and respectfully, showing the reality of medieval childbirth without being gratuitous.

JANUARY 28, 1432 - THE BIRTH

Evening - The Labor Begins

Dona Beatriz arrives within moments, takes one look at Isabel's face, and her professional calm snaps into place. "Send for Doctor Fernández and the midwife. Now."

You move toward the door but Isabel's hand shoots out, grabs your wrist. "Don't leave."

"I'm just calling them—"

"Don't leave me." Her eyes are wide, frightened beneath the control. Another contraction hits and she gasps, bending forward.

The household erupts into organized chaos. Servants rush past with linens, basins of water, herbs. Doctor Fernández arrives with his leather bag, the old midwife María close behind. They examine Isabel briefly, confer in low voices.

"First babies take time, Your Majesty," Fernández says to you. "This will be hours yet. Perhaps you should—"

"He stays," Isabel says firmly. Then to you, quieter: "Please."

So you stay.

The hours crawl past. Isabel paces when she can, grips your hand during contractions, tries to pray between them. Dona Beatriz wipes her forehead with cool cloths. The midwife María murmurs encouragement: "Good, my lady, breathe through it, that's good..."

Midnight comes and goes. The contractions grow stronger, closer together. Isabel can no longer speak during them—just grips whatever's nearest and breathes in ragged gasps.

"It's progressing well," Doctor Fernández assures you both around the second hour past midnight. "Everything as it should be."

But as dawn approaches, something changes.

Dawn - The Crisis

Isabel has been laboring for eight hours when the midwife's examination makes her face go pale. She says something low to Doctor Fernández. His expression shifts.

"Your Majesty," he says carefully to you. "Perhaps you should wait outside now. We need—"

"No." Isabel's voice is raw. "He stays."

"My lady, I really think—"

"What's wrong?" you demand.

Fernández hesitates, then: "The baby is breech. Feet first, not head. We need to try to turn it, and it's... it's not going to be pleasant."

Isabel's face goes white, but she nods. "Do it."

What follows is agony. The physician's hands pressing on Isabel's distended belly, trying to manipulate the baby from outside. Isabel screaming—actual screaming, not the gasps and cries from before. Dona Beatriz holding her shoulders. You holding her hand so tight you're afraid you'll break it, but she's holding yours just as hard.

"I can't turn it," Fernández finally says, sweat on his own brow. "The baby won't move. It's coming feet first. We'll have to deliver it that way."

The midwife María's face is grim. You've heard the stories about breech births. About babies that don't survive the delivery. About mothers who hemorrhage.

"How long?" you ask.

"However long it takes," Fernández says grimly. "My lady, when the next contraction comes, you must push. Even though it will hurt worse than anything yet."

Isabel nods, tears streaming down her face. She looks at you. "If something happens—"

"Nothing will happen."

"Juan, if they have to choose—"

"Both of you will be fine."

But you don't believe it. Not anymore. Not with the way the physicians are looking at each other.

Morning - The Desperate Hours

The sun rises over Toledo. Inside your chambers, Isabel has been pushing for three hours.

The baby's feet have emerged—tiny, purple, not moving. But the rest won't come. The body is stuck. Every contraction, every push, and barely any progress.

Isabel is beyond exhaustion. Her face is gray, drenched in sweat. She can barely hold her eyes open between contractions. The blood—there's so much blood, soaking the linens, pooling beneath her.

"We're losing too much blood," the midwife María mutters to Fernández. "If this continues—"

"I know," he snaps. Then louder, to Isabel: "My lady, the next push. You must push harder than before. We need the shoulders out NOW."

Isabel tries. God, she tries. The sound she makes isn't even human anymore—pure animal agony as she pushes with everything left in her.

Something shifts. The baby's body emerges further—torso, arms—but the head is still inside.

"The head's stuck," Fernández says, and there's real fear in his voice now. "We have seconds, maybe a minute before—"

He doesn't finish. Doesn't need to. A baby can't survive long like this, cord compressed, unable to breathe.

His hands work inside Isabel—you can see him manipulating, trying to ease the head through. Isabel is screaming again, or maybe she's too weak to scream, maybe that's just a moan that sounds like dying.

"Come on," María is praying. "Come on, come on, Blessed Mother help us—"

And then—

The baby slides free all at once, a rush of blood and fluid, tiny body limp and blue in the physician's hands.

Not crying.

Not moving.

Not breathing.

The Silence

Doctor Fernández works with desperate speed—clearing the baby's mouth and nose, rubbing the tiny chest, breathing into the impossibly small mouth. María has her hands on Isabel now, pressing hard on her belly, trying to stop the hemorrhaging that's gotten worse.

"Still bleeding," María says urgently. "Too much, it won't stop—"

"Keep pressure," Fernández orders, still working on the baby. "Come on, breathe, breathe—"

Isabel's eyes are closed. She's gray as death, barely conscious. Blood everywhere.

The baby still isn't breathing.

"Juan," Isabel whispers, so quiet you almost don't hear. "Tell them... baby first..."

"Both of you," you say fiercely. "Both."

Fernández breathes into the baby's mouth again. Rubs the chest. Again. Again.

The silence stretches impossibly long.

Then—

A tiny gasp. The smallest sound. The baby's chest hitches.

Another gasp.

Then a weak, thin cry.

"Alive," Fernández breathes. "Alive, thank God—" He wraps the baby quickly, hands it to Dona Beatriz. "Keep it warm. Watch the breathing."

He turns immediately back to Isabel. Works with María, both of them pressing, manipulating, doing something you can't see and don't understand.

"The bleeding's slowing," María says after an eternity. "I think—yes. Yes, it's stopping."

Ten minutes pass. Twenty. They keep working. Cleaning. Stitching. Checking.

Finally, Doctor Fernández straightens. His hands are covered in blood. His face is exhausted.

"They're both alive," he says simply. "Your Majesty... they're both alive."

Aftermath

Isabel lies pale and still, barely conscious. They've cleaned her, changed the linens, but she looks like she's already dead—face like wax, lips colorless, breathing so shallow you have to watch closely to see her chest move.

Dona Beatriz brings the baby—wrapped tightly, breathing but making small mewling sounds instead of healthy cries.

"A son," she says quietly. "You have a son, Your Majesty."

You barely hear her. You're kneeling beside Isabel, holding her cold hand.

Her eyes open slightly. "The baby...?"

"Alive. A boy. We have a son."

The smallest smile. "Good." Her eyes close again. "Tired..."

"My lady must rest," Doctor Fernández says firmly. "Both of them need rest. The baby's breathing isn't strong yet, and the Queen..." He pauses. "She's very weak. She lost a great deal of blood. The next few days will tell us if—" He stops himself. "She needs rest. Complete rest."

You look at your son—tiny, too still, breathing but barely. You look at your wife—alive but looking like death.

Both survived.

Barely.

The bells of Toledo ring for morning Mass, celebrating the Feast of Saint Thomas Aquinas. In your chambers, two lives hang by threads.

Your heir is born. Your wife lives.

But at what cost?

Rolled 39. Moderate Infection - Difficult Recovery


I stay by Isabel's side as much as possible and together we watch our baby girl. Draft what happens in the coming weeks using these results.

For the first day after the birth, there's cautious hope. Isabel sleeps—deep, exhausted sleep that the physicians call healing. The baby—your daughter—lies in a cradle beside the bed, tended by a wet nurse since Isabel is too weak to feed her herself.

You hold your daughter on the second day. She's impossibly tiny, wrapped in soft linens, but her eyes open and she doesn't cry. Just looks at you with dark, unfocused infant eyes. Perfect little fingers curl around your thumb.

"She's beautiful," Isabel whispers from the bed. Her voice is weak but present. "Isn't she beautiful?"

"She is."

"I'm sorry she's not a son."

"She's perfect." And you mean it. This tiny creature who survived what should have killed her—she's a miracle.

But on the third day, Isabel's fever begins.

February: The Fever

It starts subtly. Isabel complains of increased pain, more than expected. By evening she's flushed, her skin hot to the touch. Doctor Fernández examines her and his face goes grim.

"Infection," he says quietly to you outside the chamber. "Common after difficult births. We'll treat it with poultices, herbs, bloodletting. But Your Majesty... the next weeks will tell."

The fever climbs. Isabel drifts in and out of lucidity. Sometimes she knows you, reaches for your hand. Sometimes she's delirious, calling for her mother in Portuguese, reliving the birth in fragmented nightmares.

You don't leave. A pallet is brought into the chamber for you to sleep on—when you sleep at all. Mostly you sit beside her bed, holding her hand, wiping her forehead with cool cloths when the fever spikes.

The baby thrives. It's almost cruel how healthy she is—feeding vigorously from the wet nurse, gaining weight, sleeping and waking in normal patterns. While her mother burns with fever, the infant grows stronger every day.

"What should we name her?" you ask Isabel during one of her lucid moments.

She's quiet for a long time. "Catalina," she finally whispers. "After Saint Catherine. For... for surviving impossible things."

"Catalina," you repeat. "It's perfect."

A weak smile. "When will you... present her to the court?"

"When you can be there too."

"Juan, you can't wait—the kingdom needs to see the heir—"

"She's not the heir. Not yet. We'll have sons." You squeeze her burning hand. "And I'm not presenting our daughter without you there. The court can wait."

Days blur together. The physicians try everything—poultices of honey and herbs, prayers, bloodletting. Dona Beatriz and the other ladies keep constant vigil. Messages arrive from the kingdom—business that needs attention—but Álvaro handles everything. You signed a temporary delegation of routine authority. The crusade can wait. The kingdom can wait.

Your wife is dying and you will not leave her.

Mid-February: The Crisis Point

Two weeks after the birth, the fever peaks. Isabel is barely conscious, skin like fire, breathing shallow and rapid. Doctor Fernández pulls you aside.

"Your Majesty, you should... you should prepare yourself. And perhaps send for a priest."

"No."

"The infection has spread. Her body is fighting but—"

"She'll survive. She's strong."

But even you can see she's not. She's wasting away before your eyes, this girl of sixteen who gave you a daughter at such terrible cost.

That night, you kneel in the Portuguese chapel—your chapel, yours and Isabel's—and pray with more desperation than you've ever felt. Not the formal prayers of kingship or crusade. Just raw pleading.

"Don't take her. Please. Not her. Not now."

Late February: The Turning

On February 22nd, twenty-five days after the birth, Isabel's fever breaks.

Not suddenly—no dramatic moment. Just a gradual cooling through the night. By morning her skin feels closer to normal. Her eyes open and she knows you.

"Juan?"

"I'm here."

"How long...?"

"Three and a half weeks."

She tries to sit up, can't. "The baby—"

"Thriving. Catalina is perfect. She's here—see?" You gesture to the cradle. The wet nurse lifts the baby, brings her close so Isabel can see.

Catalina has filled out in three weeks. Healthy pink skin, alert eyes, making small cooing sounds. Isabel's eyes fill with tears.

"She's so big already."

"Nearly nine pounds now. The wet nurse says she eats like a warrior."

The smallest laugh, which turns into a wince. "Everything hurts."

"I know."

Doctor Fernández examines her that afternoon. Afterward, in private: "The fever's broken. The crisis has passed. But Your Majesty, she's very weak. The infection... there's damage. She'll need months to recover. Possibly longer."

"But she'll live?"

"God willing, yes. She'll live."

March: The Long Healing

Isabel improves, but painfully slowly. By early March she can sit up in bed for short periods. By mid-March she can stand with assistance, take a few shuffling steps before exhaustion forces her back to bed.

The pain is constant. The tearing from the birth, the infection—her body is healing but everything still hurts. She tries not to show it, but you see her wince with every movement, see how carefully she positions herself.

You're there for all of it. Helping her stand. Supporting her when she tries to walk. Sitting with her through the worst pain. Reading to her when she's too tired to talk.

And caring for Catalina together, as much as Isabel's strength allows.

The baby is brought to her several times daily. Isabel can't hold her for long—too weak, too painful—but she touches her daughter's face, strokes the soft dark hair, whispers to her in Portuguese.

"She has your eyes," you tell Isabel.

"And your father's chin, I think. Strong."

"She'll need to be strong." A pause. "We both will. When the court learns we have a daughter instead of a son..."

Isabel's hand finds yours. "We have time for sons. We're both young."

But there's fear underneath the words. You both know what this birth cost. The idea of going through it again...

"Later," you say firmly. "We'll think about that later. Right now you just need to heal."

One evening in mid-March, Isabel is finally strong enough to hold Catalina for more than a few minutes. She sits propped up with pillows, the baby cradled carefully in her arms. Catalina is nearly two months old now, alert and active, making sounds and grasping at things.

You sit beside them, watching. Your wife and daughter. Both alive against impossible odds.

"I thought we would both die," Isabel says quietly. "During the birth, I was certain. I prayed for the baby at least to survive, but I didn't think..." She looks down at Catalina. "She's perfect, Juan. After everything, she's perfect."

"You're both miracles."

"I'm not. Look at me—I can barely walk. Everything hurts. I'm weak and useless—"

"You survived childbirth that should have killed you. You're fighting an infection that kills most women. You're healing." You touch her face gently. "You're the strongest person I know."

She leans into your hand, tears sliding down her cheeks. "I was so frightened. I'm still frightened."

"Of what?"

"Of doing this again. Of having to give you a son. Because we need one—the kingdom needs an heir—but Juan, I don't know if I can survive another birth like that."

You gather her and Catalina both into your arms, carefully, mindful of her pain. "Then we don't. Not for a long time. Not until you're strong and ready and the physicians say it's safe. The kingdom has an heir—we have Catalina. If we never have another child, she'll rule after me."

"A queen regnant? Without a husband to—"

"Then we'll find her a good husband when she's grown. Or maybe we'll have sons later, when you're healed. But Isabel, I'm not losing you to get a male heir. Do you understand? You matter more."

She cries then—really cries, like she's been holding it in for weeks. You hold them both until she's cried herself out and Catalina has fallen asleep between you.

Late March: First Steps

By the end of March—two months after the birth—Isabel can walk unassisted for short distances. The pain is still there, but manageable. She's desperately thin, her face hollow, but there's color in her cheeks again.

She insists on attending Mass for the first time, on the Feast of the Annunciation. You help her dress—she moves so carefully, like she's made of glass—and walk with her slowly to the chapel.

When she kneels for prayer, you see the effort it costs her. But she stays for the whole Mass, praying with quiet intensity.

Afterward, in your chambers: "Thank you."

"For what?"

"For staying. For being here. For..." She gestures helplessly. "Everything. I know the kingdom needs you. The crusade—"

"Nothing was more important than being here."

"We should present Catalina soon. To the court. They need to see her."

"Are you strong enough?"

A pause. Then: "I will be. Give me another week or two. Then we'll show them our daughter."

She says it with determination, but you both know the reception will be complicated. A daughter, not a son. The succession uncertain. Nobles already calculating, planning.

But that's for later. For now, you have what matters: Isabel alive. Catalina healthy. Your family intact against all odds.

The bells of Toledo ring for vespers. In your chambers, Isabel holds Catalina while you read from the Psalms. Evening prayers, like always. The rhythm that sustained you through courtship, marriage, separation, and now crisis.

"The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want..."

Isabel's voice joins yours, weak but steady. Catalina makes small sounds, as if she's trying to join the prayer too.

Outside, spring is coming to Castile. The crusade waits. The kingdom waits. The court waits.

But in this moment, you have everything.

The next morning, a messenger arrives from Álvaro de Luna: "Your Majesty, the court must be informed. When will you present the princess?"

Well, we have three marshalls. One for each noble. We send them out to demand that they surrender their persons and come here to Toledo in captivity so I can do what justice demands. They have not acted hostile towards me, but they must understand that I am not negotiating with them.


Lets summon our marshalls.

Álvaro nods immediately. "I'll have them summoned at once."

He steps out briefly, speaks to a page in the corridor. Within twenty minutes, footsteps approach and the three Crown Marshals arrive.

Don Rodrigo de Perea enters first—the veteran commander from your eastern campaign, now wearing the distinctive regalia of his new office. His face shows concern when he sees your exhausted state, but he says nothing.

Don Pedro Fernández de Velasco follows—the Count of Haro's heir, representing one of the great houses. Young, perhaps twenty-five, but carrying himself with the confidence of his lineage.

Don García Fernández Manrique enters last—the Count of Castañeda, another great house representative. Older, maybe forty, with the bearing of a man who's navigated court politics successfully for decades.

All three bow deeply. They were appointed at the Cortes just three months ago—this is their first major test of the new system.

Don Rodrigo speaks: "Your Majesty, we came as quickly as we could. The Constable said you had urgent orders regarding the condemned nobles."

The three marshals stand before you, waiting. Behind them, Álvaro closes the chamber door for privacy. The newly created enforcement arm of the crown, ready to receive their first real orders.

The question of how to handle defiant, bitter, and negotiating nobles hangs in the air.

Men, thank you for coming.


You have witnessed the excommunication and the charges. Two are not rebelling but wanting to negotiate I guess. Understandable but unacceptable. We do not negotiate with these rebels. They are to present themselves before me in this court to stand trial for their offences. They have not rebelled so I will grant them this. 
Sotomayor is preparing for a siege. Tell him that if he does not come willingly, we will come and get him, and when we do, he cannot count on my mercy. 
You will each get an armed escort of course. It's not your job to fight, but to deliver this message, or to accept them into your custody and bring them before me.


Alvaro? Anything to add?

The three marshals listen intently, their expressions serious. Don Rodrigo nods as you speak—he knows your style from the campaign, direct and clear.

When you finish, Álvaro steps forward slightly. "Your Majesty has given clear orders. I would add only practical details for the marshals."

He turns to address them directly: "Each of you will have an escort of fifty mounted men-at-arms. Enough to ensure your safety and display crown authority, but not so many as to appear you're bringing an army. You carry writs bearing His Majesty's seal and the ecclesiastical notices of excommunication—the full legal authority of both crown and church."

He looks at each marshal in turn. "Baron de Medina has already surrendered his estates. Don García, you'll find him at his minor holding near Burgos. He should be the easiest—he's already compliant, if bitter about it. Bring him to Toledo in honorable custody."

"Count of Niebla is negotiating. Don Pedro, you'll make clear there are no negotiations. The Cortes' judgment is final. He surrenders his person and comes to Toledo for trial, or he becomes an outlaw and we come for him with the full army."

"Don García de Sotomayor..." Álvaro's voice hardens. "Don Rodrigo, you'll need to be careful. His castle is fortified. You deliver His Majesty's message, but if he refuses, you withdraw. Do not attempt to force entry with fifty men—that's suicide. Report back and we'll organize a proper siege with artillery for spring."

Álvaro glances at you to confirm this is acceptable, then back to the marshals. "Questions?"

Don Pedro Fernández de Velasco speaks: "Your Majesty, if they ask about the specific charges at trial—what they face if they surrender?"

The chamber is quiet, waiting for your response.

I have already offered them a chance to redeem themselves in the crusade. I will not take back that promise. But they must understand this is not a negotiation. They surrender themselves so I may judge their fate further. Depending on their intentions and conduct, I may look favorable on them, especially if they show true remorse. Their offence is not recognizing my and representatives authority and I cant have that. They know what they did, now they face the consequences.

Don Pedro nods, seeming satisfied with the answer. "Clear enough, Your Majesty. They submit to your judgment, with crusade service as a possible redemption."

Don García Fernández Manrique, the older marshal, adds: "And if they refuse to come? If Niebla keeps stalling or Medina decides bitter words aren't enough and he wants to resist after all?"

Álvaro answers before you need to: "Then they become outlaws in open rebellion. At that point, His Majesty's offer of potential mercy is withdrawn. We reduce their castles with the full army and they face execution, not trial."

Don Rodrigo de Perea, who will face the most difficult assignment with Sotomayor, asks quietly: "Your Majesty, if Sotomayor refuses—and I suspect he will—when do you want the siege organized? Early spring before the Granada campaign, or after?"

It's a practical question. Sotomayor's castle in Extremadura is in the opposite direction from Granada. The crusade campaign was planned to resume in late March or April. Dealing with a fortified rebel castle will take weeks, maybe months, and divert resources.

The three marshals wait for your answer. Behind them, Álvaro watches you carefully—he knows the Queen's illness complicates all these timelines, but he's letting you make the call.

Don Rodrigo, do not cencern yourself with warfare. Your job is to give them one last chance to come willingly. If we must siege his castle, his family and his followers will also suffer but that choice is between him and God. If he refuses, the excommunication stands. Just report to me that he refused, the generals and the army will take over from there. Again, it is not your job to fight. But you have my solemn word that I will make sure that if they refuse, they will be made example of. Such refusal of our authority cannot stand and I will deal with it. It is inevitable.


Do you have more questions?

Don Rodrigo bows his head. "Understood, Your Majesty. I deliver the message, report their response. The army handles any resistance."

The three marshals exchange glances. Don García Fernández Manrique speaks: "No further questions, Your Majesty. The orders are clear. We'll depart within two days—time to organize the escorts and prepare the documents."

Álvaro adds: "I'll have the writs prepared today. Royal seal, ecclesiastical documents, everything properly formatted. Each marshal will carry identical authority."

Don Pedro hesitates, then: "Your Majesty, if I may... the court is asking about the Queen. And about the birth. What may we tell people when they ask? We'll be traveling through the kingdom—word will spread from us."

It's a fair question. These three men are about to ride across Castile carrying your authority. Whatever they say about the Queen's condition and the princess will reach noble houses, towns, churches. The official story versus rumors.

The marshals wait. Outside the chamber, the palace continues its daily rhythm—servants passing, distant voices, the ordinary sounds of life continuing despite the crisis in the royal apartments.
You can tell them that Castille has a new healthy princess named Catalina. The queen has been through a very difficult birth and is recovering. Let it be known.

All three marshals bow. "A princess named Catalina," Don Pedro repeats. "We'll share the news, Your Majesty. Congratulations on your daughter."

Don García Fernández Manrique adds quietly: "And we'll pray for the Queen's swift recovery. The kingdom needs her."

Don Rodrigo meets your eyes directly—the veteran who's seen you in battle, who knows you better than the other two. "Your Majesty looks exhausted. With your permission, we'll finalize our preparations and depart as soon as the documents are ready. You should be with the Queen."

Álvaro moves toward the door, clearly preparing to escort them out and begin organizing the logistics. The three marshals wait to be dismissed.

In the corridor outside, you can hear the palace stirring—afternoon activities, courtiers moving about their business. The news about Catalina and Isabel will spread through Toledo within hours once these men begin their preparations. By the time they ride out, the whole kingdom will be talking.

The marshals stand ready, waiting to see if you have any final instructions before they begin their missions.

Álvaro hands you the sealed parchment. The wax seal bears the Portuguese royal arms - the five blue shields on white. You break it open and unfold the letter.

The script is formal, written by a royal secretary, but the words carry weight:

To Our Most Beloved Son-in-Law, Juan II, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León,

We rejoice to hear news of the birth of Our granddaughter, the Princess Catalina. God has blessed your union with fruit, and We offer prayers of thanksgiving for this gift.

However, We have also received reports that Our beloved daughter Isabel has suffered gravely in bringing this child into the world, and that she now lies ill with fever. As a father, We confess Our heart is troubled. Isabel is Our youngest daughter, and though she is now Queen of Castile and under your care, she remains precious to Us.

We write not to interfere in the affairs of your kingdom, but as a father concerned for his child. If you would find it helpful, We would gladly send Our own royal physicians - men who attended Isabel throughout her childhood and know her constitution well. They could travel to Toledo within two weeks of receiving your word.

We also extend an offer to Queen Isabel herself: should she desire the comfort of her mother during this difficult time, the Queen of Portugal stands ready to travel to Toledo to be with her daughter. We know that in times of illness, a mother's presence can bring solace that even the best physicians cannot provide.

These offers come with no conditions and no expectations beyond a father's desire to aid his daughter in her suffering. We trust in your care of her, but if Portuguese assistance would ease her recovery, it is freely given.

We await word of Isabel's improvement with anxious hearts. Know that masses are being said daily in Lisbon for her swift recovery and for the health of the Princess Catalina.

May God keep you both in His grace,

João, by the Grace of God King of Portugal and the Algarves

Written at Lisbon, this 3rd day of February, Year of Our Lord 1432

The letter is formal in structure but the concern is genuine. A father worried about his sixteen-year-old daughter nearly dying in childbirth in a foreign land.

Álvaro watches your face as you read. "He's not overstepping," he says quietly. "But if you accept... Portuguese physicians, the Queen of Portugal in Toledo... it could be seen as a sign that our own doctors aren't sufficient. Or it could simply be seen as family caring for family."

He waits to see how you'll respond.

To Hell with that!
She needs her mother, and she speaks Portugese in her fever dreams. Of course we let them come!


I am angry.


I grab a piece of paper and hand it to Alvaro and I dictate a response.


Dear father in law, king of Portugal, ect,


I have always thought that leading a crusade would be my greatest battle and my greatest test. But seeing my sweet and delicate Isabel suffer like she did during childbirth has tested me beyond anything I saw on any battlefield. Never in my life have I felt so helpless.


She has spoken often of her mother and although she is in no condition to speak right now, I know that having her mother by her side would be of great comfort to her. Any Portugere physicians would be greatly appreciated. We do what we can, but having her own Portugese aides by her side would be of great help.


Your letter has reached me during this difficult time and will read it to Isabel next time she wakes. I appreciate it greatly and warms my heart. I look forward to meeting you as family, hopefully under better and less stressful circumstances. Catalina is growing strong and she would love to meet her grandfather, Im sure.


Until then,


Juan king of Castille.

Álvaro's quill scratches rapidly across the parchment as you dictate, his expression softening as he writes. When you finish, he reads it back to ensure accuracy, then looks up.

"Your Majesty..." He pauses, seeming to choose his words carefully. "This is honest. Raw. King João will appreciate it - not the formal diplomatic language, but a son speaking to a father about his daughter."

He sets down the quill. "I'll have it sealed with your personal seal and dispatched immediately by fast courier. If they leave today, it could reach Lisbon in four days. The Queen of Portugal and physicians could be here within two weeks, perhaps sooner if they ride hard."

Álvaro stands, holding the letter carefully. "The court will talk about Portuguese royalty coming to Toledo. Some will say it shows weakness, that we couldn't handle our own affairs. Others will see it as proper - family caring for family in crisis." He meets your eyes directly. "But Your Majesty is right. The Queen needs her mother. To hell with what the court thinks."

It's rare to hear Álvaro speak so bluntly, setting aside political calculation for simple human decency.

"I'll see this sent immediately. Is there anything else you need before you return to the Queen?" He glances toward the door leading back to your chambers, where Isabel lies fevered and Isabel's ladies keep their vigil.

Outside, the afternoon bells ring. Another day passing in this week of crisis.

events.summary: Juan returns to Isabel's bedside. She is feverish and barely conscious but recognizes him. He tells her that her mother is coming from Portugal and reads King Joao's letter aloud to her. Isabel is overcome with emotion and relief, crying at the news. She admits she wanted to ask for her mother but feared appearing weak. Through the afternoon, Juan waits at her side until Catalina wakes for feeding. The wet nurse reports Catalina is thriving — feeding vigorously, gaining weight, perfectly healthy.

exchanges.text:
You know where to find me. Come to me when we hear back from the marshalls.


I go to Isabel. 
Stop and let the player generate a dialogue for Juan if the moment arrives.

Álvaro bows. "I will, Your Majesty. As soon as word arrives."

You leave the council chamber and make your way back through the corridors to your apartments. The guards outside snap to attention as you approach. Inside, the room is dim - curtains drawn against the afternoon light to keep Isabel comfortable.

Dona Beatriz rises from her chair beside the bed as you enter. Her face is tired - she's barely left Isabel's side all week. The wet nurse sits in the corner with Catalina, who's sleeping peacefully in her arms.

Isabel lies against the pillows, face flushed with fever. Her hair is damp with sweat, plastered to her forehead. She's breathing, but shallowly. A basin of water sits beside the bed with cloths for cooling her fever.

As you approach, Isabel's eyes flutter open slightly. She seems to recognize you through the fever haze.

"Juan...?" Her voice is barely a whisper, hoarse from days of illness.

Dona Beatriz quietly withdraws a few steps to give you privacy, though she remains close enough to assist if needed. The wet nurse continues rocking Catalina gently in the corner.

Isabel's hand moves weakly on the coverlet, as if reaching for you.

I take her hand.


Isabel... I have recieved a letter from your father. I have asked if your mother can come visit us. I expect her to be here in a few weeks. Do you like that Isabel?

Isabel's eyes widen slightly, tears immediately forming. Her grip on your hand tightens with what little strength she has.

"My mother?" Her voice breaks. "She's... she's coming?"

A tear slides down her feverish cheek. She tries to say something in Portuguese but it comes out garbled, confused by the fever. She swallows hard, tries again in Castilian.

"I've wanted... I wanted to ask but I thought... thought you'd think me weak. A child calling for her mother." Another tear. "But Juan, I've been so frightened. So alone. And I keep dreaming of home, of Lisbon, of..."

She trails off, exhausted by even this brief speech. Her breathing is labored. But she's looking at you with something like desperate hope breaking through the fever.

Dona Beatriz moves closer with a cool cloth, gently wiping Isabel's forehead. "Hush now, my lady. Save your strength. The King has sent for your mother. She'll be here soon."

Isabel's eyes don't leave your face. Her hand still grips yours.

"Thank you," she whispers. "Thank you, Juan. I... I love you."

Then her eyes close again, exhausted. Her breathing settles back into the shallow, feverish rhythm. But her hand doesn't let go of yours.

Dona Beatriz looks at you with profound gratitude. "Your Majesty made the right choice. When the fever breaks and she's more lucid, knowing her mother is coming... it will help her fight."

From the corner, Catalina makes a small sound in her sleep. The wet nurse adjusts her gently.
I take a look at Catalina. Is she awake?

You move quietly to the corner where the wet nurse sits. She looks up at your approach and carefully adjusts the bundle in her arms so you can see better.

Catalina is asleep - deeply asleep in that boneless way of newborns. She's grown noticeably even in just a week. Her face has filled out, losing some of that wrinkled newborn look. Dark hair, surprisingly thick for an infant, peeks out from the soft linen wrapping.

She's breathing perfectly - strong, steady, none of the weakness from those first terrifying hours. Her tiny fists are curled near her face, and as you watch, she makes a small sucking motion in her sleep.

The wet nurse - a woman named María from a Toledo merchant family - speaks softly: "She fed well an hour ago, Your Majesty. Very vigorous. She's gaining weight properly - the physician checked this morning and was very pleased. Strong lungs too, when she wants something."

As if to prove the point, Catalina shifts slightly and makes a small sound - not quite waking, just the normal movements of infant sleep.

She looks nothing like the blue, silent creature the physician held up a week ago. She's pink, healthy, perfect. A miracle, the physicians keep saying. After such a birth, she should not be this healthy.

Behind you, Isabel shifts in the bed, muttering something feverish and incomprehensible. The contrast is stark - the mother who nearly died, still fighting infection, and the daughter who emerged unscathed.

The wet nurse watches your face carefully, waiting to see if you want to hold her.
I wait at Isabel's side until either Isabel or Catalina fullyu wakes.

The afternoon passes slowly. You sit beside Isabel's bed, holding her hand, watching the rise and fall of her fevered breathing. Dona Beatriz and the other ladies move quietly about the room - refreshing water basins, replacing cooling cloths, tending to small tasks. The wet nurse rocks Catalina gently in the corner.

Outside, the sounds of Toledo drift through the closed shutters - distant market calls, church bells marking the hours, the ordinary life of the city continuing while your world contracts to this one room.

Isabel drifts in and out. Sometimes her eyes flutter open but don't focus. Sometimes she mutters in Portuguese - fragments about her childhood, her mother, prayers. Once she grips your hand tighter and whispers "the baby?" and you tell her Catalina is here, she's perfect, and Isabel relaxes back into fevered sleep.

The light changes. Afternoon becomes evening. Vespers bells ring.

Around the seventh hour past noon, Catalina begins to stir. Small sounds at first - the mewling cries of a hungry infant. The wet nurse stands, checking, then looks to you.

"She's waking, Your Majesty. She'll want to feed soon."

Catalina's cries grow stronger - not distressed, just insistent. The healthy, demanding cry of a thriving baby. Her tiny fists wave, face scrunching up.

At the sound, Isabel's eyes open. More focused than before, though still glazed with fever. She turns her head slightly toward the crying.

"Is that...?" Her voice is hoarse but clearer than it's been all day.

Dona Beatriz moves to her side immediately. "The princess is waking, my lady. Just hungry."

Isabel tries to push herself up slightly, winces at the pain, but her eyes are on the wet nurse holding Catalina. "Can I... can I see her?"

Juan then hands Catalina back to the wet nurse for feeding and sits with Isabel, who asks about her mother's arrival timeline. He reads King Joao's letter to her again when she is more lucid. exchanges.text:
I take Cataline from the wet nurse and gently hold her against Isabel's chest.


Look at this wonder of God's grace Isabel. She is beautiful

You lift Catalina carefully from the wet nurse's arms - she's surprisingly solid for something so small, warm and squirming slightly. Her crying quiets to small fussy sounds as you move. You settle beside Isabel on the bed, supporting the baby's head as you gently lower her against Isabel's chest.

Isabel's arms come up weakly to cradle her daughter. The effort costs her - you can see the exhaustion in every movement - but she holds on. Catalina settles against her mother's chest, the crying stopping almost immediately. Just small breathing sounds now, the infant's face turned toward Isabel.

"She's so warm," Isabel whispers. Tears stream down her fevered face. "So perfect. Look at her little fingers..."

One of Catalina's tiny hands has escaped the wrapping, fingers curling and uncurling. Isabel touches them gently with one finger and the baby's hand closes around it instinctively - that automatic newborn grasp.

Isabel makes a sound between a laugh and a sob. "She's holding me. Juan, she's holding my finger."

Dona Beatriz stands nearby, ready to help if Isabel's strength fails, but for now she just watches. The wet nurse hovers anxiously - clearly worried about feeding time being delayed but not daring to interrupt this moment.

Isabel looks down at Catalina, then up at you. Her face is still flushed with fever, her hair damp with sweat, dark circles under her eyes. But in this moment there's something else too - wonder, love, fierce protectiveness despite her weakness.

"We made her," Isabel says softly. "She's ours."

Catalina makes a small sound and her mouth moves - clearly starting to root, looking for food. Isabel winces slightly as the baby moves against her tender body.

I hand Catalina back to the wet nurse to let her feed.


I sit with Isabel.


Your mother must be on her way. I look forward to meeting her.

The wet nurse takes Catalina gently and moves back to her corner, beginning to feed the hungry infant. The small nursing sounds fill the quiet room.

Isabel watches them go, reluctant to let her daughter leave even for feeding. Then she turns her attention back to you, her hand finding yours again on the coverlet.

"My mother..." Isabel's voice is still weak but clearer than it's been in days. "She'll be so worried. When she hears how bad the birth was, how sick I've been..." A tear slides down. "She'll think she's going to lose me."

She squeezes your hand. "What did you tell my father? In your letter?"

Dona Beatriz quietly refills the water basin, giving you privacy while remaining close enough to assist if needed. Outside, the evening bells ring for compline. The winter darkness is settling over Toledo.

Isabel's eyes are on your face, waiting. Despite the fever, despite the exhaustion, she's more present now than she's been all day. As if talking about her mother, knowing she's coming, has given her something to hold onto.

"How long before she arrives?" Isabel asks. "Two weeks? Three?" There's both hope and impatience in her voice - a sick child wanting her mother, counting the days.

A few more weeks I think.


I take the letter from her father and read it to her in full.

You retrieve the letter from where you'd set it on the side table. The Portuguese royal seal is broken, the parchment slightly crumpled from being carried in your pocket. You settle back beside Isabel, unfolding it carefully.

"Let me read you what your father wrote."

Isabel nods weakly, her eyes fixed on the letter bearing her father's seal.

You read it aloud, translating the formal diplomatic language into something simpler where needed. As you progress through the words - the joy at Catalina's birth, the father's concern for his daughter, the offer of physicians and the Queen's own presence - you watch Isabel's face.

Fresh tears come when you reach the part about her mother being ready to travel. By the time you get to the closing - masses being said daily in Lisbon - Isabel is crying openly, though trying to stay quiet so as not to disturb Catalina's feeding.

"He called me his beloved daughter," she whispers when you finish. "Even though I'm Queen of Castile now, I'm still... I'm still his little girl."

She tries to wipe her face but her hands are shaking. Dona Beatriz moves forward with a cloth, gently dabbing Isabel's tears.

"My mother is coming," Isabel says, as if she needs to say it aloud to believe it. "She's really coming. She'll..." Her voice breaks. "She'll know what to do. She always knows what to do when I'm ill."

She looks at you, fever-bright eyes searching your face. "You're not angry? That I need my mother? Some kings would think it weakness, or interference..."

I give her a kiss.


Dont worry Isabel. You have done something amazing, you have given me a daughter.


Now, can I give you something to eat? Do you think you can have something?

Isabel leans into the kiss weakly, then settles back against the pillows. Your words about Catalina bring a small, exhausted smile to her fevered face.

At the mention of food, she hesitates. Her hand goes to her stomach - still swollen and tender from the birth - and she winces slightly.

"I... I don't know. I haven't eaten more than broth in days. Everything hurts too much." She pauses, looking guilty. "The physicians keep saying I need to eat to recover strength, but Juan, even swallowing hurts. My throat is so dry from the fever."

Dona Beatriz steps forward. "Your Majesty, we have chicken broth keeping warm. And fresh bread soaked in wine - very soft, easy to swallow. Perhaps just a few bites? The Queen needs strength to fight the infection."

Isabel looks uncertain, clearly exhausted at the very thought of eating. But she's trying to be cooperative.

"I can try," she says weakly. "If you think it will help." She shifts slightly in the bed, trying to sit up more, and gasps at the pain the movement causes. "God, everything still hurts so much..."

Dona Beatriz and another lady move to help prop her up with more pillows, being careful of her injuries. Isabel grits her teeth through it, breathing hard when they're finished.

She looks at you, waiting to see what you'll do. In the corner, Catalina has finished feeding and the wet nurse is gently burping her.
